article.title: Bo%C3%B6tes
article.paragraph: BotesIPAc-enboʊˈoʊtiːzis aconstellationin the northern sky, located between 0 and +60declination, and 13 and 16 hours ofright ascensionon thecelestial sphere. The name comes from theAncient GreekGreek,Bots, meaningherderherdsmanorplowman(literally, ox-driver; frombouscow). The "" in the name is aDiaeresis (diacritic)diaeresis, not anUmlaut (linguistics)umlaut, meaning that each 'o' is to be pronounced separately.

One of the 48 constellations described by the 2nd century astronomerPtolemy, Botes is now one of the 88 modern constellations. It contains theList of brightest starsfourth brightest starin the night sky, the orange-huedArcturus. Botes is home to many other bright stars, including eight above the fourth magnitude and an additional 21 above the fifth magnitude, making a total of 29 stars easily visible to the naked eye.
article.heading: History and mythology
article.paragraph: In ancient Babylon the stars of Botes were known as SHU.PA. They were apparently depicted as the godEnlil, who was the leader of the Babylonian pantheon and special patron of farmers.sfnWhite2008207

The nameBoteswas first used byHomerin hisOdysseyas a celestial reference point forHistory of navigation#Antiquitynavigation,Homer, Odyssey,book 5, 272described as "late-setting" or "slow to set", translated as the "Plowman".sfnMandelbaum1990103Exactly whom Botes is supposed to represent inGreek mythologyis not clear. According to one version, he was a son ofDemeter,Levy 1996 pp=141Philomenus, twin brother ofPlutus, a ploughman who drove the oxen in the constellationUrsa Major.sfnRidpath200188–89This is corroborated by the constellation's name, which itself means "ox-driver" or "herdsman."Levy 1996 pp=141The ancient Greeks saw theasterism (astronomy)asterismnow called the "Big Dipper" or "Plough" as a cart with oxen.sfnThompsonThompson2007102This influenced the name's etymology, derived from the Greek for "noisy" or "ox-driver".sfnStar Tales BoötesAnother myth associated with Botes tells that he invented theplowand was memorialized for his ingenuity as a constellation.sfnPasachoff2000133

Another myth associated with Botes byHyginusis that ofIcarius, who was schooled as a grape farmer and winemaker byDionysus. Icarius made wine so strong that those who drank it appeared poisoned, which caused shepherds to avenge their supposedly poisoned friends by killing Icarius.Maera (hound)Maera, Icarius's dog, brought his daughterErigone (daughter of Icarius)Erigoneto her father's body, whereupon both she and the dog committed suicide. Zeus then chose to honor all three by placing them in the sky as constellations: Icarius as Botes, Erigone asVirgo (constellation)Virgo, and Maera asCanis MajororCanis Minor.sfnStar Tales Boötes

Following another reading, the constellation is identified withArcasand also referred to as Arcas and Arcturus, son ofZeusandCallisto (mythology)Callisto. Arcas was brought up by his maternal grandfatherLycaon (Arcadia)Lycaon, to whom one day Zeus went and had a meal. To verify that the guest was really the king of the gods, Lycaon killed his grandson and prepared a meal made from his flesh. Zeus noticed and became very angry, transforming Lycaon into a wolf and gave back life to his son. In the meantime Callisto had been transformed into a she-bear, by Zeus's wife,Hera, who was angry at Zeus's infidelity.sfnRidpath200188–89sfnStar Tales BoötesThis is corroborated by the Greek name for Botes,Arctophylax, which means "Bear Watcher".sfnStar Tales BoötesCallisto in form of a bear was almost killed by her son who was out hunting. Zeus rescued her, taking her into the sky where she became Ursa Major, "the Great Bear". The name Arcturus (the constellation's brightest star) comes from the Greek word meaning "guardian of the bear". SometimesArcturusis depicted as leading the hunting dogs of nearbyCanes Venaticiand driving the bears of Ursa Major andUrsa Minor.Levy 1996 pp=141

link.target: File:Sidney Hall - Urania's Mirror - Bootes, Canes Venatici, Coma Berenices, and Quadrans Muralis.jpg
link.part: Botes as depicted in ''Urania's Mirror'', a set of constellation cards published in London c.1825. In his left hand he holds his hunting dogs, Canes Venatici. Below them is the constellation Coma Berenices. Above the head of Botes isQuadrans Muralis, now obsolete, but which lives on as the name of the early JanuaryQuadrantidmeteor shower.Mons Mnaluscan be seen at his feet.

article.paragraph: Severalformer constellationswere formed from stars now included in Botes.Quadrans Muralis, the Quadrant, was a constellation created near Beta Botis from faint stars.sfnMoore2000341–342It was invented in 1795 byJrme Lalande, an astronomer who used aquadrant (instrument)quadrantto perform detailedastrometryastronometric measurements. Lalande worked withNicole-Reine Lepauteand others to predict the 1758 return ofHalley's Comet. Quadrans Muralis was formed from the stars of eastern Botes, westernHercules (constellation)Hercules, andDraco (constellation)Draco.sfnLevy200851It was originally calledLe MuralbyJean Fortinin his 1795Atlas Cleste; it was not given the nameQuadrans MuralisuntilJohann Bode's 1801Uranographia. The constellation was quite faint, with its brightest stars reaching the 5th magnitude.sfnStar Tales Quadrans MuralisMons Maenalus, representing theMaenalusmountains, was created byJohannes Heveliusin 1687 at the foot of the constellation's figure. The mountain was named for the son of Lycaon,Maenalus. The mountain, one ofDiana (mythology)Diana's hunting grounds, was also holy toPan (mythology)Pan.sfnStar Tales Mons Maenalus
article.heading: Non-Western astronomy
article.paragraph: The stars of Botes were incorporated into many differentChinese astronomyChinese constellations. Arcturus was part of the most prominent of these, variously designated as the celestial king's throne (Tian Wang) or the Blue Dragon's horn (Daijiao); the nameDaijiao, meaning "great horn", is more common. Arcturus was given such importance in Chinese celestial mythology because of its status marking the beginning of the lunar calendar, as well as its status as the brightest star in the northern night sky. Two constellations flankedDaijiao,Youshetito the right andZuoshetito the left; they represented companions that orchestrated the seasons.Zuoshetiwas formed from modernZeta BootisZeta,Omicron BootisOmicron, andPi Botis, whileYoushetiwas formed from modernEta BootisEta,Tau BootisTau, andUpsilon Botis.Dixi, the Emperor's ceremonial banquet mat, was north of Arcturus, consisting of the stars12 Bootis12,11 Bootis11, and9 Botis. Another northern constellation wasQigong, the Seven Dukes, which was mostly across the Botes-Hercules border. It included eitherDelta BotisorBeta Botisas its terminus.sfnStar Tales Boötes

The other Chinese constellations made up of the stars of Botes existed in the modern constellation's north; they are all representations of weapons.Tianqiang, the spear, was formed fromIota BootisIota,Kappa BootisKappa, andTheta Botis;Genghe, variously representing a lance or shield, was formed fromEpsilon BootisEpsilon,Rho BootisRho, andSigma Botis. There were also two weapons made up of a singular star.Xuange, thehalberd, was represented byLambda Botis, andZhaoyao, either the sword or the spear, was represented byGamma Botis.sfnStar Tales Boötes

Two Chinese constellations have an uncertain placement in Botes.Kangchi, the lake, was placed south of Arcturus, though its specific location is disputed. It may have been placed entirely in Botes, on either side of the Botes-Virgo border, or on either side of the Virgo-Libra border. The constellationZhouding, a bronze tripod-mounted container used for food, was sometimes cited as the stars1 Bootis1,2 Bootis2, and6 Botis. However, it has also been associated with three stars in Coma Berenices.sfnStar Tales Boötes
article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: Botes is a constellation bordered by Virgo to the south,Coma Berenicesand Canes Venatici to the west, Ursa Major to the northwest, Draco to the northeast, andHercules,Corona BorealisandSerpens Caputto the east. The three-letter abbreviation for the constellation, as adopted by theInternational Astronomical Unionin 1922, is 'Boo'.sfnRussell1922469The official constellation boundaries, as set byEugne Joseph DelporteEugne Delportein 1930, are defined by a polygon of 16 segments. In theequatorial coordinate system, theright ascensioncoordinates of these borders lie betweenRA1336.1andRA1549.3, while thedeclinationcoordinates stretch from +7.36 to +55.1.sfnIAU, ''The Constellations'', BoötesCovering 907 square degrees, Botesculminationculminatesat midnight around 2 May and ranks 13th in area.sfnBakich1995150

Colloquially, its pattern of stars has been likened to a kite or ice cream cone.sfnBakich1995150sfnPolakis2009However, depictions of Botes have varied historically.Aratusdescribed him circling the north pole, herding the two bears. Later ancient Greek depictions, described by Ptolemy, have him holding the reins of his hunting dogs (Canes Venatici) in his left hand, with a spear, club, or staff in his right hand.sfnStar Tales BoötesAfter Hevelius introduced Mons Maenalus in 1681, Botes was often depicted standing on thePeloponnesemountain.sfnStar Tales Mons MaenalusBy 1801, when Johann Bode published hisUranographia, Botes had acquired a sickle, which was also held in his left hand.sfnStar Tales Boötes

The placement of Arcturus has also been mutable through the centuries. Traditionally, Arcturus lay between his thighs, as Ptolemy depicted him. However,Germanicus Caesardeviated from this tradition by placing Arcturus "where his garment is fastened by a knot".sfnStar Tales Boötes
article.heading: Notable features

link.part: The constellation Bootes as it can be seen by the naked eye.

article.heading: Stars
article.paragraph: see alsoList of stars in BoötesIn hisUranometria,Johann Bayerused the Greek letters Alpha through to Omega and then A to k to label what he saw as the most prominent 35 stars in the constellation, with subsequent astronomers splitting Kappa, Mu, Nu and Pi as two stars each. Nu is also the same star as Psi Herculis.sfnWagman200355–57John Flamsteednumbered 54 stars for the constellation.sfnWagman2003355–56

Located 36.7light-yearsfrom Earth,Arcturus, or Alpha Botis, is the brightest star in Botes and the fourth brightest star in the sky at anapparent magnitudeof 0.05;sfnSIMBAD Alpha BoötisIt is also the brightest star north of thecelestial equator, just shading outVegaandCapella.sfnMoore2000341–342sfnMooreTirion1997132–133Its name comes from the Greek for "bear-keeper". Anorange giantofspectral classK1.5III,sfnSIMBAD Alpha BoötisArcturus is an ageing star that has exhausted its core supply of hydrogen and cooled and expanded to a diameter of 27solar diameters,sfnRidpath200188–89equivalent to approximately 32 million kilometers.sfnMoore2000341–342Though its mass is approximately onesolar mass(Solar massy),sfnRidpath200188–89Arcturus shines with 133 times the luminosity ofsolar luminositythe Sun(Solar luminosityy).sfnKaler ArcturusBayer located Arcturus above the herdsman's left knee in hisUranometria. NearbyEta Botis, or Muphrid, is the uppermost star denoting the left leg.sfnWagman2003503It is a 2.68-magnitude star 37 light-years distant with a spectral class of G0IV,sfnSIMBAD Eta Boötisindicating it has just exhausted its core hydrogen and is beginning to expand and cool. It is 9 times as luminous as the Sun and has 2.7 times its diameter. Analysis of its spectrum reveals that it is aspectroscopic binary.sfnKaler MuphridMuphrid and Arcturus lie only 3.3 light years away from each other. Viewed from Arcturus, Muphrid would have a visual magnitude of -2, while Arcturus would be around visual magnitude -4 when seen from Muphrid.sfnSchaaf2008136

Marking the herdsman's head is Beta Botis,sfnWagman2003503or Nekkar, ayellow giantof magnitude 3.5 and spectral type G8IIIa.sfnSIMBAD Beta BoötisLike Arcturus, it has expanded and cooled off themain sequencelikely to have lived most of its stellar life as a blue-whiteB-type main sequence star.sfnKaler NekkarIts common name comes from the Arabic phrase for "ox-driver". It is 219 light-years awaysfnRidpath200188–89and has a luminosity ofSolar luminosity58y.sfnMoore2000341–342Located 86 light-years distant,Gamma Botis, or Seginus, is a white giant star of spectral class A7III,sfnSIMBAD Gamma Boötiswith a luminosity 34 times and diameter 3.5 times that of the Sun.sfnKaler SeginusIt is aDelta Scuti variable, ranging between magnitudes 3.02 and 3.07 every 7 hours.sfnAAVSO Gamma BoötisThes stars are short period (six hours at most) pulsating stars that have been used asCosmic distance ladder#Standard candlesstandard candlesand as subjects to studyastroseismology.sfnAAVSO Delta Scuti VariablesDelta Botisis a wide double star with a primary of magnitude 3.5 and a secondary of magnitude 7.8. The primary is a yellow giant that has cooled and expanded to 10.4 times the diameter of the Sun.sfnKaler Delta BoötisOf spectral class G8IV, it is around 121 light-years away,sfnSIMBAD Delta Boötiswhile the secondary is a yellow main sequence star of spectral type G0V.sfnSIMBAD BD+33 2562The two are thought to take 120,000 years to orbit each other.sfnKaler Delta BoötisMu Botis, known asAlkalurops, is a triple star popular with amateur astronomers. It has an overall magnitude of 4.3 and is 121 light-years away. Its name is from the Arabic phrase for "club" or "staff". The primary appears to be of magnitude 4.3 and is blue-white. The secondary appears to be of magnitude 6.5, but is actually a close double star itself with a primary of magnitude 7.0 and a secondary of magnitude 7.6. The secondary and tertiary stars have an orbital period of 260 years.sfnRidpath200188–89The primary has an absolute magnitude of 2.6 and is of spectral class F0.sfnMoore2000341–342The secondary and tertiary stars are separated by 2 arcseconds; the primary and secondary are separated by 109.1 arcseconds at an angle of 171 degrees.sfnThompsonThompson2007106Nu Botisis an optical double star. The primary is an orange giant of magnitude 5.0 and the secondary is a white star of magnitude 5.0. The primary is 870 light-years away and the secondary is 430 light-years.

Epsilon Botis, also known asIzarorPulcherrima, is a close triple star popular with amateur astronomers and the most prominent binary star in Botes. The primary is a yellow-sfnThompsonThompson2007105or orange-hued magnitude 2.5 giant star, the secondary is a magnitude 4.6 blue-huedmain-sequence star,sfnRidpath200188–89and the tertiary is a magnitude 12.0 star.sfnThompsonThompson2007105The system is 210 light-years away. The name "Izar" comes from the Arabic word for "girdle" or "loincloth", referring to its location in the constellation. The name "Pulcherrima" comes from the Latin phrase for "most beautiful", referring to its contrasting colors in a telescope.sfnRidpath200188–89The primary and secondary stars are separated by 2.9arcsecondsat an angle of 341 degrees; the primary's spectral class is K0 and it has a luminosity ofSolar luminosity200y.sfnMoore2000341–342sfnThompsonThompson2007105To the naked eye, Izar has a magnitude of 2.37.sfnMoore2000341–342NearbyRho BotisRhoandSigma Botisdenote the herdsman's waist.sfnWagman2003503Rho is an orange giant of spectral type K3III located around 160 light-years from Earth.sfnSIMBAD Rho BoötisIt is ever so slightly variable, wavering by 0.003 of a magnitude from its average of 3.57.sfnAAVSO Rho BoötisSigma, aF-type main sequence staryellow-white main sequence starof spectral type F3V, is suspected of varying in brightness from 4.45 to 4.49.sfnAAVSO Rho BoötisIt is around 52 light-years distant.sfnSIMBAD Sigma Boötis

Traditionally known asAl Auld al Dhibah(-al auld al dhib), "the Whelps of the Hyenas",Theta BotisTheta,Iota BotisIota,Kappa BotisKappaandLambda Botisare a small group of stars in the far north of the constellation. The magnitude 4.05Theta Botishas a spectral type of F7 and an absolute magnitude of 3.8.Iota Botisis a triple star with a primary of magnitude 4.8 and spectral class of A7,sfnMoore2000341–342a secondary of magnitude 7.5,sfnRidpath200188–89and a tertiary of magnitude 12.6.sfnThompsonThompson2007105The primary is 97 light-years away.sfnRidpath200188–89The primary and secondary stars are separated by 38.5 arcseconds, at an angle of 33 degrees.sfnMoore2000341–342The primary and tertiary stars are separated by 86.7 arcseconds at an angle of 194 degrees. Both the primary and tertiary appear white in a telescope, but the secondary appears yellow-hued.sfnThompsonThompson2007105Kappa Botisis another wide double star. The primary is 155 light-years away and has a magnitude of 4.5. The secondary is 196 light-years away and has a magnitude of 6.6.sfnRidpath200188–89The two components are separated by 13.4 arcseconds, at an angle of 236 degrees.sfnMoore2000341–342The primary, with spectral class A7, appears white and the secondary appears bluish.sfnThompsonThompson2007105An apparent magnitude 4.18Ap and Bp starstype A0p star,sfnMoore2000341–342Lambda Botisis the prototype of a class of chemically peculiar stars, only some of which pulsate asDelta Scutitype stars. The distinction between the Lambda Botis stars as a class of stars with peculiar spectra, and the delta Scuti stars whose class describes pulsation in low-overtone pressure modes, is an important one. While many Lambda Botis stars pulsate and are delta Scuti stars, not many delta Scuti stars have Lambda Botis peculiarities, since the Lambda Botis stars are a much rarer class whose members can be found both inside and outside the delta Scuti instability strip. Lambda Botis stars aredwarf starsthat can be either spectral class A or F.sfnNorth2004145Like BL Botis-type stars they are metal-poor.sfnGood200362Scientists have had difficulty explaining the characteristics of Lambda Botis stars, partly because only around 60 confirmed members exist, but also due to heterogeneity in the literature. Lambda has an absolute magnitude of 1.8.sfnMoore2000341–342

There are two dimmer F-type stars, magnitude 4.8312 Botis, class F8; and magnitude 4.9345 Botis, class F5.sfnMoore2000341–342Xi Botisis a G8 yellow dwarf of magnitude 4.55, and absolute magnitude is 5.5. Two dimmer G-type stars are magnitude 4.8631 Botis, class G8, and magnitude 4.7644 Botis, class G0.sfnMoore2000341–342

Of apparent magnitude 4.06,Upsilon Botishas a spectral class of K5 and an absolute magnitude of 0.3. Dimmer than Upsilon Botis is magnitude 4.54Phi Botis, with a spectral class of K2 and an absolute magnitude of 0.1. Just slightly dimmer than Phi at magnitude 4.60 isO Botis, which, like Izar, has a spectral class of K0. O Botis has an absolute magnitude of 0.2. The other four dim stars are magnitude 4.916 Botis, class K4; magnitude 4.8620 Botis, class K3; magnitude 4.81Omega Botis, class K4; and magnitude 4.83A Botis, class K1.sfnMoore2000341–342

There is one bright B-class star in Botes; magnitude 4.93Pi1 BotisPi1Botis, also called Alazal. It has a spectral class of B9 and is 40 parsecs from Earth. There is also one M-type star, magnitude 4.8134 Botis. It is of class gM0.sfnMoore2000341–342
article.heading: Multiple stars
article.paragraph: File:Celestial photograph of Bootes.jpg500pxthumbnailleftCelestial photograph depicting many of Botes' double and multiple stars. Arcturus is the bright white star in the lower right. The semicircle of stars near the bottom left is the neighboring constellationCorona Borealis.Besides Pulcherrima and Alkalurops, there are several other binary stars in Botes:

list.listitem: Xi Botisis a quadruple star popular with amateur astronomers. The primary is a yellow star of magnitude 4.7 and the secondary is an orange star of magnitude 6.8. The system is 22 light-years away and has an orbital period of 150 years.sfnRidpath200188–89The primary and secondary have a separation of 6.7 arcseconds at an angle of 319 degrees.sfnMoore2000341–342The tertiary is a magnitude 12.6 star (though it may be observed to be brighter) and the quaternary is a magnitude 13.6 star.sfnThompsonThompson2007105

Pi Botisis a close triple star. The primary is a blue-white star of magnitude 4.9, the secondary is a blue-white star of magnitude 5.8,sfnRidpath200188–89and the tertiary is a star of magnitude 10.4.sfnThompsonThompson2007105The primary and secondary components are separated by 5.6 arcseconds at an angle of 108 degrees;sfnMoore2000341–342the primary and tertiary components are separated by 128 arcseconds at an angle of 128 degrees.sfnThompsonThompson2007105

Zeta Botisis a triple star that consists of abinary starphysical binarypair with andouble staropticalcompanion. Lying 205 light-years away from Earth, The physical pair has a period of 123.3 years and consists of a magnitude 4.5 and a magnitude 4.6 star. The two components are separated by 1.0 arcseconds at an angle of 303 degrees. The optical companion is of magnitude 10.9, separated by 99.3 arcseconds at an angle of 259 degrees.44 Botisis an eclipsing variable star. The primary is of variable magnitude and the secondary is of magnitude 6.2; they have an orbital period of 225 years. The components are separated by 1.0 arcseconds at an angle of 40 degrees.sfnMoore2000341–342

article.paragraph: 44 Botis(i Botis) is a double variable star 42 light-years away. It has an overall magnitude of 4.8 and appears yellow to the naked eye. The primary is of magnitude 5.3 and the secondary is of magnitude 6.1; their orbital period is 220 years. The secondary is itself an eclipsing variable star with a range of 0.6 magnitudes; its orbital period is 6.4 hours.sfnRidpath200188–89It is aW Ursae Majoris variablethat ranges in magnitude from a minimum of 7.1 to a maximum of 6.5 every 0.27 days. Both stars are G-type stars. Another eclipsing binary star isZZ Botis, which has two F2-type components of almost equal mass,sfnPopper 1983and ranges in magnitude from a minimum of 6.79 to a maximum of 7.44 over a period of 5.0 days.sfnAAVSO ZZ Boötis
article.heading: Variable stars
article.paragraph: Two of the brighter Mira-type variable stars in the constellation areR BotisRandS Botis. Both are red giants that range greatly in magnitudefrom 6.2 to 13.1 over 223.4 days,sfnPasachoff2000199–200sfnMoore2000341–342and 7.8 to 13.8 over a period of 270.7 days respectively.sfnMoore2000341–342Also red giants,V BotisVandW Botisaresemi-regular variable starsthat range in magnitude from 7.0 to 12.0 over a period of 258 days, and magnitude 4.7 to 5.4 over 450 days respectively.sfnMoore2000341–342

BL Botisis the prototype of its class of pulsating variable stars,sfnNorth2004123theanomalous Cepheids. These stars are somewhat similar toCepheid variables, but they do not have the same relationship between their period and luminosity.sfnGood200361Their periods are similar toRRAB variables; however, they are far brighter than these stars.sfnGood200369BL Botis is a member of the clusterNGC 5466. Anomalous Cepheids aremetallicitymetal poorand have masses not much larger than the Sun's, on average,Solar mass1.5y. BL Botis type stars are a subtype ofRR Lyraevariables.sfnGood200370

T Botiswas anovaobserved in April 1860 at a magnitude of 9.7. It has never been observed since, but that does not preclude the possibility of it being a highly irregularvariable staror arecurrent nova.sfnMooreTirion1997132–133
article.heading: Stars with planetary systems

link.part: A digital rendering of Tau Botis b

article.paragraph: Extrasolar planetshave been discovered encircling ten stars in Botes as of 2012.Tau Botisis orbited by a large planet, discovered in 1999. The host star itself is a magnitude 4.5 star of type F7V, 15.6parsecsfrom Earth. It has a mass ofSolar mass1.3yand a radius of 1.331solar radiussolar radii(Solar radiusy); a companion,GJ527B, orbits at a distance of 240 AU.Tau Botis b, the sole planet discovered in the system, orbits at a distance of 0.046 AU every 3.31 days. Discovered throughradial velocitymeasurements, it has a mass of 5.95Jupiter masses(Jupiter massy).sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia Tau Boo bThis makes it ahot Jupiter.sfnRodlerLopez-MoralesRibas2012The host star and planet aretidal locktidally locked, meaning that the planet's orbit and the star's particularly high rotation are synchronized.sfnCameron et al. 2000sfnWalker et al.2008Furthermore, a slight variability in the host star's light may be caused by magnetic interactions with the planet.sfnWalker et al.2008Carbon monoxideis present in the planet's atmosphere. Tau Botis b does notastronomical transittransitits star, rather, its orbit is inclined 46 degrees.sfnRodlerLopez-MoralesRibas2012Like Tau Botis b,HAT-P-4 bis also a hot Jupiter. It is noted for orbiting a particularlymetallicitymetal-richhost star and being of low density.sfnKovács et al.2007Discovered in 2007, HAT-P-4 b has a mass ofJupiter mass0.68and a radius ofJupiter radius1.27. It orbits every 3.05 days at a distance of 0.04 AU.HAT-P-4, the host star, is an F-type star of magnitude 11.2, 310 parsecs from Earth. It is larger than the Sun, with a mass ofSolar mass1.26and a radius ofSolar radius1.59.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HAT-P-4 b

link.part: Evolution of the HD 128311 system over time

article.paragraph: Botes is also home to multiple-planet systems.HD 128311is the host star for a two-planet system, consisting ofHD 128311 bandHD 128311 c, discovered in 2002 and 2005, respectively.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 128311 bsfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 128311 cHD 128311 b is the smaller planet, with a mass ofJupiter mass2.18; it was discovered throughradial velocityobservations. It orbits at almost the same distance as Earth, at 1.099 AU; however, its orbital period is significantly longer at 448.6 days.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 128311 bThe larger of the two, HD 128311 c, has a mass ofJupiter mass3.21and was discovered in the same manner. It orbits every 919 days inclined at 50, and is 1.76 AU from the host star.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 128311 cThe host star, HD 128311, is a K0V-type star located 16.6 parsecs from Earth. It is smaller than the Sun, with a mass ofSolar mass0.84and a radius ofSolar radius0.73; it also appears below the threshold of naked-eye visibility at an apparent magnitude of 7.51.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 128311 b

There are several single-planet systems in Botes.HD 132406is a Sun-like star of spectral type G0V with an apparent magnitude of 8.45, 231.5 light-years from Earth.sfnDa Silva Udry et al.2007It has a mass ofSolar mass1.09and a radius ofSolar radius1.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 132406The star is orbited by a gas giant,HD 132406 b, discovered in 2007.sfnDa Silva Udry et al.2007HD 132406 orbits 1.98 AU from its host star with a period of 974 days and has a mass ofJupiter mass5.61. The planet was discovered by the radial velocity method.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 132406WASP-23is a star with one orbiting planet,WASP-23 b. The planet, discovered by thetransit methodin 2010, orbits every 2.944 very close to its Sun, at 0.0376 AU. It is smaller than Jupiter, atJupiter mass0.884andJupiter radius0.962. Its star is a K1V type star of apparent magnitude 12.7, far below naked-eye visibility, and smaller than the Sun atSolar mass0.78andSolar radius0.765.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia WASP-23 bHD 131496is also encircled by one planet,HD 131496 b. The star is of type K0 and is located 110 parsecs from Earth; it appears at a visual magnitude of 7.96. It is significantly larger than the Sun, with a mass ofSolar mass1.61and a radius of 4.6 solar radii. Its one planet, discovered in 2011 by theradial velocity method, has a mass ofJupiter mass2.2; its radius is as yet undetermined. HD 131496 b orbits at a distance of 2.09 AU with a period of 883 days.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 131496 b

Another single planetary system in Botes is theHD 132563system, atriple starsystem. The parent star, technicallyHD 132563B, is a star of magnitude 9.47, 96 parsecs from Earth. It is almost exactly the size of the Sun, with the same radius and a mass only 1% greater. Its planet,HD 132563B b, was discovered in 2011 by the radial velocity method.Jupiter mass1.49, it orbits 2.62 AU from its star with a period of 1544 days.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 132563B bIts orbit is somewhat elliptical, with anOrbital eccentricityeccentricityof 0.22. HD 132563B b is one of very few planets found in triple star systems; it orbits the isolated member of the system, which is separated from the other components, aspectroscopic binary, by 400 AU.sfnDesidera et al.2011Also discovered through the radial velocity method, albeit a year earlier, isHD 136418 b, a 2-Jupiter mass planet that orbits the starHD 136418at a distance of 1.32 AU with a period of 464.3 days. Its host star is a magnitude 7.88 G5-type star, 98.2 parsecs from Earth. It has a radius ofSolar radius3.4and a mass ofSolar mass1.33.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia HD 136418 b

WASP-14 bis one of the most massive and dense exoplanets known,sfnJoshi et al.2009with a mass ofJupiter mass7.341and a radius ofJupiter radius1.281. Discovered via the transit method, it orbits 0.036 AU from its host star with a period of 2.24 days.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia WASP-14 bWASP-14 b has a density of 4.6 grams per cubic centimeter, making it one of the densest exoplanets known.sfnJoshi et al.2009Its host star,WASP-14, is an F5V-type star of magnitude 9.75, 160 parsecs from Earth. It has a radius ofSolar radius1.306and a mass ofSolar mass1.211.sfnExoplanet Encyclopedia WASP-14 bIt also has a very high proportion oflithium.sfnJoshi et al.2009
article.heading: Deep-sky objects
article.paragraph: Botes is in a part of thecelestial spherefacing away from the plane of our homeMilky Waygalaxy, and so does not have open clusters or nebulae. Instead, it has one brightglobular clusterand many faintgalaxygalaxies.sfnThompsonThompson2007102The globular clusterNGC 5466has an overall magnitude of 9.1 and a diameter of 11 arcminutes.sfnMoore2000341–342It is a very loose globular cluster with fairly few stars and may appear as a rich, concentratedopen clusterin a telescope. NGC 5466 is classified as aShapley-Sawyer Concentration Class12 cluster, reflecting its sparsity.sfnThompsonThompson2007103Its fairly large diameter means that it has a lowsurface brightness, so it appears far dimmer than the catalogued magnitude of 9.1 and requires a large amateur telescope to view. Only approximately 12 stars are resolved by an amateur instrument.sfnThompsonThompson2007104

Botes has two bright galaxies.NGC 5248(Caldwell catalogCaldwell45) is aHubble sequencetype Sc galaxy(a variety ofspiral galaxy) of magnitude 10.2. It measures 6.5 by 4.9 arcminutes.sfnMoore2000341–34250 million light-years from Earth, NGC 5248 is a member of theVirgo Clusterof galaxies; it has dim outer arms and obviousH II regions,dust lanes, and youngstar clusters.sfnNikschBlock2004NGC 5676is another type Sc galaxy of magnitude 10.9. It measures 3.9 by 2.0 arcminutes.sfnMoore2000341–342Other galaxies includeNGC 5008, a type Scemission-line galaxy,sfnSIMBAD NGC 5008NGC 5548, a type SSeyfert galaxy,sfnSIMBAD NGC 5548NGC 5653, a type S HII galaxy,sfnSIMBAD NGC 5653NGC 5778(also classified as NGC 5825),sfnSIMBAD NGC 5825a type E galaxy that is the brightest of its cluster,sfnSIMBAD NGC 5778NGC 5886,sfnSIMBAD NGC 5886andNGC 5888, a type SBb galaxy.sfnSIMBAD NGC 5888NGC 5698is a barred spiral galaxy, notable for being the host of the 2005 supernovaSN 2005bc, which peaked at magnitude 15.3.

Further away lies the 250 million light-year diameterBotes void, a huge space largely empty of galaxies. Discovered byRobert Kirshnerand colleagues in 1981, it is roughly 700 million light years from Earth.sfnRefSchilling2011179Beyond it and within the bounds of the constellation, lie twosuperclustersat around 830 million and 1 billion light years distant.
TheHerculesCorona Borealis Great Wall, the largest known structure in the Universe, covers a significant part of Botes.
article.heading: Meteor showers
article.paragraph: File:Quad2011.324.JPGthumbleftA Quadrantid captured by an all-sky camera during a 4-second exposure.Botes is home to theQuadrantidmeteor shower, the most prolific annual meteor shower. It was discovered in January 1835 and named in 1864 by Alexander Hershell.sfnJenniskens2006357–368Theradiant (meteor shower)radiantis located in northern Botes near Kappa Botis,sfnJenniskens2006612in its namesake former constellation ofQuadrans Muralis. Quadrantid meteors are dim, but have a peak visible hourly rate of approximately 100 per hour on January 34.sfnRidpath200188–89sfnMooreTirion1997132–133Thezenithal hourly rateof the Quadrantids is approximately 130 meteors per hour at their peak; it is also a very narrow shower. The Quadrantids are notoriously difficult to observe because of a low radiant and often inclement weather. The parent body of the meteor shower has been disputed for decades;sfnJenniskens2006357–368however,Peter Jenniskenshas proposed2003 EH12003 EH1, a minor planet, as the parent.sfnJenniskens20063682003 EH1may be linked toC/1490 Y1C/1490 Y1, a comet previously thought to be a potential parent body for the Quadrantids.sfnJenniskens2006373sfnJenniskens20063762003 EH1is ashort-period cometof theJupiter family cometJupiter family; 500 years ago, it experienced a catastrophic breakup event. It is now dormant.sfnJenniskens2012The Quadrantids had notable displays in 1982, 1985, and 2004.sfnLevy200849Meteors from this shower often appear to have a blue hue and travel at a moderate speed of 41.543 kilometers per second.sfnLevy2008104

On April 28, 1984, a remarkable outburst of the normally placidAlpha Bootidswas observed by visual observer Frank Witte from 00:00 to 2:30 UTC. In a 6 cm telescope, he observed 433 meteors in a field of view nearArcturuswith a diameter of less than 1.Peter Jenniskenscomments that this outburst resembled a "typical dust trail crossing".sfnJenniskens2006199The Alpha Bootids normally begin on April 14, peaking on April 27th and 28th, and finishing on May 12.sfnLevy2008110Its meteors are slow-moving, with a velocity of 20.9 kilometers per second.sfnIAU Alpha BootidsThey may be related to Comet73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 3, but this connection is only theorized.sfnLevy2008110

link.part: A bright Quadrantid observed at twilight.

article.paragraph: TheJune Bootids, also known as the Iota Draconids, is a meteor shower associated with the comet7P/Pons-Winnecke, first recognized on May 27, 1916 by William F. Denning.sfnJenniskens2006334The shower, with its slow meteors, was not observed prior to 1916 because Earth did not cross the comet's dust trail until Jupiter perturbed Pons-Winnecke's orbit, causing it to come within 0.03astronomical unitAUof Earth's orbit the first year the June Bootids were observed. In 1982, E. A. Reznikov discovered that the 1916 outburst was caused by material released from the comet in 1819.sfnJenniskens2006335Another outburst of the June Bootids was not observed until 1998, because Comet Pons-Winnecke's orbit was not in a favorable position. However, on June 27, 1998, an outburst of meteors radiating from Botes, later confirmed to be associated with Pons-Winnecke, was observed. They were incredibly long-lived, with trails of the brightest meteors lasting several seconds at times. ManyMeteoroid#Fireballfireballs, green-hued trails, and even some meteors that cast shadows were observed throughout the outburst, which had a maximum zenithal hourly rate of 200300 meteors per hour.sfnJenniskens2006336–337In 2002, two Russian astronomers determined that material ejected from the comet in 1825 was responsible for the 1998 outburst.sfnJenniskens2006338Ejectafrom the comet dating to 1819, 1825, and 1830 was predicted to enter Earth's atmosphere on June 23, 2004. The predictions of a shower less spectacular than the 1998 showing were borne out in a display that had a maximum zenithal hourly rate of 1620 meteors per hour that night. The June Bootids are not expected to have another outburst in the next 50 years.sfnJenniskens2006339–344Typically, only 12 dim, very slow meteors are visible per hour; the average June Bootid has a magnitude of 5.0. It is related to theAlpha Draconidsand theBootids-Draconids. The shower lasts from June 27 to July 5, with a peak on the night of June 28.sfnLevy2008113The June Bootids are classified as a class III shower (variable),sfnAMS 2012 Listand has an average entry velocity of 18 kilometers per second. Its radiant is located 7 degrees north of Beta Botis.sfnAMS June 23

TheBeta Bootidsis a weak shower that begins on January 5, peaks on January 16, and ends on January 18. Its meteors travel at 43 kilometers/second.sfnLevy2008105TheJanuary Bootidsis a short, young meteor shower that begins on January 9, peaks from January 16 to January 18, and ends on January 18th.sfnLevy2008106ThePhi Bootidsis another weak shower radiating from Botes. It begins on April 16, peaks on April 30 and May 1, and ends on May 12.sfnLevy2008110Its meteors are slow-moving, with a velocity of 15.1 km/s. They were discovered in 2006.sfnIAU Phi BootidsThe shower's peak hourly rate can be as high as 6 meteors per hour. Though named for a star in Botes, the Phi Bootid radiant has moved intoHercules (constellation)Hercules.sfnKoedSherrod200352The meteor stream is associated with three different asteroids:1620 Geographos,2062 Aten, and1978 CA.sfnŠtohlPorubčan199343TheLambda Bootids, part of theBootid-Coronae Borealid Complex, are a weak annual shower with moderately fast meteors; 41.75 km/s.sfnIAU Lambda BootidsThe complex includes the Lambda Bootids, as well as theTheta Coronae BorealidsandXi Coronae Borealids.sfnIAU Bootid-Coronae Borealid ComplexsfnGreen2007All of the Bootid-Coronae Borealid showers areJupiter family cometshowers; the streams in the complex have highly inclined orbits.sfnJenniskens2012

There are several minor showers in Botes, some of whose existence is yet to be verified. TheRho Bootidsradiate from near the namesake star, and were hypothesized in 2010.sfnIAU Rho BootidsThe average Rho Bootid has an entry velocity of 43 km/s.sfnIAU Rho BootidssfnBrownWongWerykWiegert2010It peaks in November and lasts for 3 days. The Rho Bootid shower is part of theSMA complex, a group of meteor showers related to theTaurids, which is in turn linked to the comet2P/Encke. However, the link to the Taurid shower remains unconfirmed and may be a chance correlation.sfnBrownWongWerykWiegert2010Another such shower is theGamma Bootids, which were hypothesized in 2006. Gamma Bootids have an entry velocity of 50.3 km/s.sfnIAU Gamma BootidsTheNu Bootids, hypothesized in 2012, have faster meteors, with an entry velocity of 62.8 km/s.sfnIAU Nu Bootids
